spiral.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a line in the form of a curve that winds around a central point, moving further away from the centre all the time
spiral.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a process, usually a harmful one, in which something gradually but continuously gets worse or better
spiral.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The company is in a downward spiral.
Unemployment rose and the city went into a spiral of decline.
spiral.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to move in a continuous curve that gets nearer to or further from its central point as it goes round
spiral.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The damaged plane spiralled to the ground.
spiral.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if a situation spirals, it gets worse, more violent etc in a way that cannot be controlled
spiral.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Crime has spiraled out of control.
spiral.translation[1].definitions[2].def: if debt or the cost of something spirals, it increases quickly in a way that cannot be controlled
spiral.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a process, usually a harmful one, in which something continuously rises, falls, gets worse etc, often starting off slowly but gradually speeding up until it is out of control
spiral.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Sales are on a downward spiral.
The current oil price rise may cause an inflationary spiral and, in the end, a recession.
spiral.translation[3].definitions[0].def: if debt or the cost of something spirals, it increases quickly and uncontrollably
spiral.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Spiralling costs may force staff cuts.
Inflation is spiralling out of control.
